The firetrail turns into a narrow bushtrail along the way.
Find the scramble up the ridge marked with painted arrows near the end of the trail.
At the top of the ridge follow the firetrail to the left.
Partway down the firetrail a paved path leads to a lookout.
Follow the pathway back to the carpark at the Park Office.
Across the carpark along the road a trail leads up to the tram platform.

markers.title: Ding Ding Ding!
explanation: You may be here on the lucky few days there is a historic tram ride to the Sydney Tramway Museum outside the park.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
On Holidays and Sundays there may be an antique tram service to Loftus.
Follow the trail along the tramway to the Loftus Oval.
Follow the Rawson Parade Trail to the traffic lights across the Princess Highway.
Cross at the traffic lights and enter the Loftus Station carpark.
Plan your return trip from Loftus at transportnsw.info.

description: This walk traverses the Royal National Park along a variety of trails.
From Waterfall Station it follows the Couranga walking track to the Forest Island.
It then follows Lady Carrington Drive for a short distance, before crossing the Curra Moors to the coast.
After a short stretch of the Coast Track the walk finishes in Helensburgh via the Burgh Track.

markers.description: Get the train to Waterfall using transportnsw.info.
Turn left from the station stairs and cross the carpark.
A staircase leads down to the trail from the far end of the carpark.
Follow the narrow bush trail away from the station.
Cross the overgrown cricket field to the fire trails on the other end.
Continue down Uloola Firetrail past the gate.
Find the sign to the Couranga Track on the right.
Follow the Couranga Track down the ridge into thick rainforest vegetation.
Find the sign to the carpark leading to a rocky creek crossing.
+1km|0.25h If the creek is flooded, follow the Couranga Track and continue along the road instead.
Cross the creek across the exposed rocks. They can be slippery.
Directly across the creek a steep bushy trail leads up the ridge.
At the intersection with the Forest Path, follow the sign to the carpark.
From the carpark follow Lady Carington drive.
Find the start of the Walumurra Track on the right.
Follow the Walumurra Track, passing several overgrown boardwalks along the way.
Eventually the track turns into steep steps up a cliff.
At the top of the cliff, continue along the firetrail.
The firetrail finally ends at Sir Bertram Stevens Drive.
Follow the road a little way to the left.
Find the gate to the Curra Moors Firetrail on the right.
At the intersection follow the Curra Moors Track to the right.
At the next intersection turn left (not to the car park).
Eventually the Curra Moors Track joins the Coast Track. Follow it to the right.

markers.title: Tadaa!
explanation: Even after many kilometres of coast, this place still manages to astonish.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
From Garie North Head follow the sandstone steps down to the beach.
Cross Garie Beach to the surf club. The water is no potable.
Continue past the surf club along the narrow rocky path to Little Garie Beach.
Follow the path across the headland to the North Era Campground.
Cross North Era Beach and follow the trail up the next headland.
Cross South Era Beach and follow the trail up the next headland.
From the South Era headland follow the trail up the escarpment.
The trail turns into steep steps towards the top.
Cross the Garawarra carpark at the trailhead.
Look for the sign to the Burgh Track on the right near the end of the carpark.
Follow the Burgh Track down the ridge to Lady Wakehurst Drive.
Cross Lady Wakehurst Drive and continue on the Burgh Track on the other side.
Cross the creek across the large boulders. Mind the slippery ones.
Follow the Burgh Track signs to Helensburgh up the ridge.
At the intersection with the Hacking River Fire Trail, follow it to the right.
The trail passes a landfill and finally ends at Halls Road.

markers.title: It Looked Like a Shortcut
explanation: It's the road less travelled. Maybe for good reason.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
From the intersection with Halls Road follow the firetrail to the right around the houses.
The trail ends on a ridge overlooking the station. There are steps down to the Station carpark.
Plan your return trip from Helensburgh at transportnsw.info.

description: The trail from Wentworth Falls to McMahons Point
offers a very long walk way out into the National Park along a very well maintained road.
There are many incidental lookouts and hostorical sites to see along the way.

markers.description: Get the train to Wentworth Falls using transportnsw.info.
From the station follow the Great Western Highway to the left and enter Table Land Road on the right.
Plan your drive to the Queen Victoria Sanitorium.
At the old sanitorium follow Kings Table Land Road to the left.
At the intersection with Andersons Trail, follow Kings Table Land Road to the right.
At the intersection follow Kings Table Land Road straight ahead.
At the intersection, follow Kings Table Land Road to the right.
A notable landmark to the right along the trail is the Battleship Tops rock formation. 0.25h / 0.1km
From the carpark at McMahons Point a narrow bush trail leads to the lookout.
After returning to the lookout carpark, follow Kings Table Land road back to the old sanitorium.
From the old sanitorium a short side trip to Sunset Rock Lookout is possible. 0.5h / 0.5km
From the abandoned hospital follow Tableland road back to the highway and Wentworth Falls Station.
Plan your return trip from Wentworth Falls at transportnsw.info.

description: The Charles Darwin Walk leads from the town centre to the falls.
Side trips to the the bottom of the falls and Rocket Point lookout start and end at from the top of the falls.
From there depending on track closures the National Pass
or Overcliff-Undercliff Tracks
all lead to the Conservation Hut cafe.
To extend the walk it's easy to add the Nature Track starting and ending at the Valley of the Waters picnic area.

markers.description: Get the train to Wentworth Falls using transportnsw.info.
From the station follow Station Street and cross the Great Western Highway.
Turning right from the crossing, enter Wilson Park on the left.
Start down Darwins Walk at the far end of the park.
Follow Darwins walk along the creek down the gully.
Climb down Weeping Rock or take the detour if this section if closed.
From Weeping Rock follow the trail and cross Wentworth Falls along the step stones.
+ 0.5h / 1km Optionally take the side trail up the narrow gully directly after the falls.
Follow the signs to Rocket Point for another lookout across the falls.
From rocket point a loop of bushtrails leads back to the falls.
Follow the path along the cliff, which turns into a very long section of steps down.
Follow the path around the bottom of the falls.
From the far end of the falls follow the Federal Pass, or the detour down Wentworth Pass.
Both options end up at the foot of Sylvia Falls, from which a series of steps continues.
Follow the path up to the top of Empress Falls.
Take the staircases out of the gully.
At the intersection go directly up to the Conservation Hut, or continue on for the Nature Trail
+ 1h / 3km From the intersection follow the track to the right up the gully.
At the top of the gully the trail passes several rock formations across the valley.
From the intersection follow the directions to the picnic area.
Keep following the signs to the picnic area past the trailheads along the way.
Find the Shortcut Track down the steps from the kiosk.
Follow the Shortcut Track to the carpark for the lookouts.
Cross the carpark to find Jamison Lookout.
Continue along the footpath to Wentworth Falls Lookout.
From Wentworth Falls Lookout follow the sign to the Falls down the hiking trail.
Follow Wentworth Falls Lookout Track to the top of the falls.
From the top of the falls follow the sign to Wentworth Station, retracing your steps along Darwins Walk.
Plan your return trip from Wentworth Falls at transportnsw.info.

description: From the Wildflower Garden this walk
crosses Mona Vale Road, the walk continues into Garigal National Park.
At the Cascades at Belrose,
the trail continues along Middle Harbour
to the Roseville Bridge.

markers.description: Get the train to Ku-ring-gai Wildflower Garden using transportnsw.info.
The bus stops near the Wildflower Garden, which is well worth a visit too.
Cross at the traffic lights and walk down Kitchener Street.
At the right turn in the road, follow the firetrail that starts at the gate to the left.
Follow the zigzag down and to the left into Garrigal National Park.
The firetrail goes past the recycling centre and down into the gully. Continue to the right after the creek.
At the junction of firetrails, continue to the left down the Bare Creek trail.
The fire trail crosses a creek and continues on to another junction.
At the junction follow the directions down the Cascades Track.
The track crosses another creek, before going on to the cascades.
Cross the cascades and follow the trail to the right.
The trail follows the steadily widening creek away from the cascades.
The next promiment landmark along the creek is a pipe line crossing.
The path turns left to follow a side creek for some distance.
At a set of cascades the trail crosses this side creek and follows it back down.
The trail gradually becomes a road along Middle Harbour.
Eventually the trail ends at a gate to Davidson Park picnic area.
Follow the picnic area to the Roseville Bridge.
Take the road from the park up to the bridge and cross it.
On the other side of the bridge, take the underpass to end up on Babbage Road.
From the bridge, follow the suburban streets to Roseville Station.
Plan your return trip from Roseville at transportnsw.info.

description: The Blue Gum Swamp is somewhat of a local secret unspoiled by tourist busses.
There is a choice between two paths, one through the gully and one across the ridge, both are worthwhile choices, each has unique scenery.
Where the two trails meet back up, a long harsh climb makes you earn the breathtaking unfenced lookout at the end.

markers.description: Plan your trip to the Winmalee Shopping Centre using transportnsw.info.
Continue past the shopping center until the road ends at the carpark for the park entrance.
Follow the firetrail the continues past the gate.
A sign at the split in the trail offers either the Blue Gum Swamp or Shaws Ridge. Both are valid.
Either trail ends at a sign pointing to Grose Head South, wich should be followed.
The trail zig zags up hill and ends at another sign. Follow it to Grose Head South
The firetrail ends at the lookout. Please be very careful near the edge.
From the end of the firetrail a narrow path starts following the cliff line.
The rough trail continues along several more lookout spots.

markers.title: Shhh, it's a Secret
explanation: Leave a friendly note in the geocache logbook. That it can lie here undisturbed means you're in a special place.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
From the lookouts retrace your steps, but take the other route back at the fork between the Blue Gum Swamp or Shaws Ridge.
Plan your return trip from Winmalee Shopping Centre at transportnsw.info.

description: This walk follows a self guided tour along a restored section of the historic Old Great North Road.
The numbered signs along the trail correspond with recorded segments in the Convict Road app available from your phone's app store.
The greater walk follows the complete Devines Hill loop to Dubbo Gully with many more views and historical roadworks along the way.

markers.description: Plan your drive to Wisemans Ferry.
From the carpark follow the restored section of the road past the gate.
The numbered exhibits all have a corresponding audio play in the app that goes with the walk.
At the intersection follow Finches Line to the right to continue the audio tour.
Watch to the right for several lookouts across Wisemans Ferry.
To the left watch for several views across Dharug National Park.
At the end of Finch line the trail zigzags back down the hill.
The trail eventually ends back at Wisemans Ferry Road
Follow Wisemans Ferry Road back to the carpark the right for the 3 hour / 12 km short version of this walk. -5h / 23km
The shorter walk back passes by Wisemans Ferry. Mind the traffic exiting en entering the ferry.
The shortcut ends back at the carpark near the gate.
For the longer version of the walk follow Wisemans Ferry Road to the left.
Follow Wisemans Ferry road past the farms towards the next hill.
At the intersection at the corner turn left up the Western Commission Trail.
Pass the gate and continue along the trail.
Watch for many incidental lookouts along the trail.
At the intersection follow the Great North Road to the left.
There are several historical roadworks to visit along the Great North Road.
At the intersection with Finches Line, follow the restored section of the Great North Road back down to the carpark.
Plan your drive back from Wisemans Ferry.

description: From the Wollongong Lighthouse the walk follows the Grand Pacific Drive along the foot and bike paths up coast.
Puckey's Estate Nature Reserve and the Seacliff Bridge are notable landmarks along the way.
The bike paths have since been extended to Stanwell Park, adding a few kilometres to this walk and a chance to enjoy the cafes and restaurants at the end.

markers.description: Get the train to Wollongong using transportnsw.info.
From the station follow Station Street and then Crown Street to the shopping mall.
Follow the mall and continue along Crown Street past the stadium to the beach.
Cross Lang Park to the footpath to the lighthouse.
From the ligthouse follow Endeavour Drive and continue around the harbour.
Take the footpath to the rockpools and continue on to North Wollongong Beach.
From the North Wollongong Beach carpark follow the footpath through the park.
The path ends on Squires Way. Cross the bridge and enter the Puckeys Estate directly after.
Follow the boardwalk and footpath through Puckeys Estate to Towradgi Beach.
From the surf club follow the beach or the bike path to Towradgi Beach.
Walk around Towradgi Point and continue along the beach to Bellambi Point.
Walk around Belambi Point and follow the road from the carpark to Bellambi Beach.
Follow  Bellambi Beach or the bike path along the beach to the Woonona Rock Pool.
From  the Woonona Rock Pool follow Bulli Beach to Waniora Point.
Walk around Waniora Point and follow Sandon Point Beach.
Continue around Sandon Point and follow McCauleys Beach.
At the end of Thirroul Beach walk around the headland via the road.
From the Austinmer surf club cross the beaches and follow the road around Brickyard Point.
Follow the footpath after Brickyard Point past Sharky Beach.
Walk along Lawrence Hargrave Drive past Coledale Beach.

markers.title: Oh, I get it: Friend-Ship
explanation: The most wholesome pun along the Grand Pacific Drive.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Continue along Lawrence Hargrave Drive through Wombarra, Scarborough, and Clifton.
Cross the Seacliff Bridge along the footpath.

markers.title: Between a Rock and a Hard Place
explanation: The temporary answer to the Illwarra crumbling into the ocean.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
After the bridge turn right through Coalcliff and follow the signs to the station.
The Station is a short distance up Lawrence Hargrave Drive from Coalcliff.
Get the train to Coalcliff using transportnsw.info.

description: This walk is a unique experience, requiring the train to make a special stop at the remote and inaccessible Wondabyne Station.
From there the walk follows the Wondabyne to Patonga walking track to Mount Wondabyne,
with a possible side trip down Tommos Loop
to nearby Staples Lookout.
After completing the trek across Mount Wondabyne, this walk leaves the Patonga walking track at the intersection of firetrails and heads to the park exit at the Woy Woy landfill.
Make sure to board the rear door of the train to Wondabyne and warn the guard that you want alight at Wondabyne Station, otherwise the train will not stop.

markers.description: Get the train to Wondabyne using transportnsw.info.
From the Wondabyne Train Station follow the Great North Walk signs up the ridge.
At the top of the ridge follo the Great North Walk markers up the Rifle Range Trail.
At the intersection with the Hawkesbury Trail follow the sign to Patonga.
Follow the markers along the Hakesbury Trail down the ridge.
The trail through the gully passes a waterfall.
On the other side of the waterfalls steps lead back up the ridge.
Follow the trail out of the gully to the intersection with Tommos Loop Firetrail.
+ 1h / 4km To add Staples Lookout to the walk follow Tommos Loop to the left.
Follow the firetrail to Woy Woy Road.
Follow Woy Woy Road to the left for a short distance.
Cross Woy Woy Road at the carpark for Staples Lookout
Retrace your path back down Tommos Loop to the junction with the Great North Walk.
From the intersection with the Hakesbury track follow the sign to Patonga.
Follow the trail and boardwalks in the direction of Mount wondabyne.
At the junction follow Mullet Creek Firetrail to the right.
A sign on the side of the firetrail will indicated the bushtrail up Mount Wondabyne.
Climb the steps and zig zag trail up the slope of Mount Wondabyne.
At the top of the climb an intersection leads to the summit or onwards down the other side.
+ 0.5h / 0.5km Optionally climb the summit of Mount Wondabyne.

markers.title: This is the End
explanation: The end is just the start of a new journey.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
From the summit follow the firetrail down the other side of the hill.
At intersection with the Tunnel Firetrail Follow the Great North Walk Markers.
Instead of following the Great North Walk to Patonga, follow Dillons Firetrail out of the park.
The trail ends at a gate into the landfill.
Follow the road out of the landfill past the waste water treatment plant.
If the gate at the bottom of the hill is closed, find the gap for pedestrians on the right side.
From the railway underpass, follow Railway Street all the way to Woy Woy Station.
Plan your return trip from Woy Woy at transportnsw.info.

description: From the pleasant Woy Woy foreshore footpaths, this walk leads past Blackwall up to the Daleys Point Walking Track.
After climbing the ridge and a side trip to the nearby Daleys Point Aboriginal Rock Art
the walk follows a stretch of the Bouddi Ridge Explorer all the way to the Bouddi National Park entrance.
From the park entrance the longer Strom Loop leads to
the far end of Maitland Bay Beach via the Mount Bouddi Walking Track,
or the shorter Maitland Bay Track can be taken down to the near end of the beach.
From the beach the Bouddi Coastal Walk is followed
to the Killcare Surf Club.
Using the road up from the surf club the walk follows the dirt road to Box Head along the top of the ridge.
From the carpark there the Flanel Flower Walking Track leads to the foreshore of Pretty Beach,
with an optional side trip to the secluded Lobster Beach.
After following the foreshore around Hardy's Bay a rough bushtrail ascends the ridge up to the Allan Strom Lookout
at the end of the Rocky Point Trail.
From the trail's carpark begins a retrace of the route back to Woy Woy.

markers.description: Get the train to Woy Woy using transportnsw.info.
From the station follow Brisbane Water Drive to the ferry jetty and follow the footpath along the shore from there.
Follow the path around Lions Park.
From the other side of Lions Park, follow the footpath along the shore.
From the end of the path follow Blackwall Road along the left side of the mountain to the bridge.
Cross the Bridge and follow Daley Ave to the steep ramp up the firetrail on the left hand side.
At the top of the right follow Fishermans Trail to the left.
+ 0.5h / 1km At the intersection with Daleys Point Trail turn left to visit the rock engravings and lookout.
From the intersection with Fishermans Trail follow Daleys Point Trail to the car park.
From the carpark cross the road and follow Maitland Bay Drive to the visitor centre of Bouddi national park.
From the park office, follow the firetrail left to Mount Bouddi.
- 1.5h / 5km Alternatively follow the staircase directly down to Maitland bay.
Follow Stroms Trail to the gate follow Mount Bouddi Road right to the carpark and picnic area.
From the picnic area follow the Mount Bouddi Track down to Maitland Bay.
At the intersection with the Bouddi Coastal Walk follow the trail to the right down to Maitland Bay.
From Maitland Bay, follow the Bouddi Coastal Walk towards Putty Beach.
After taking the wooden staircase down, follow Putty Beach to the Killcare surf club on the far end.
From the surf club, follow Beach Drive up to the roundabout and follow Hawke Head Drive to the left.
- 2h / 8km Optionally from the roundabout follow Killcare Road down to the shops.
From the Box Head car park, follow the sign to the Flannel Flower Trail.
Follow the Flannel Flower Trail to Wagstaffe.
+ 0.5h / 1km Optionally along the way, follow the sign left to Lobster Beach.
From the end of the bush trail, follow Albert Street down to the ferry dock.
From the ferry dock, follow Pretty Beach Road to Hardys Bay along the water.
From the shops at Hardys Bay, continue along Araluen Drive along the water and climb the trail along Fraser Road up the ridge.
+ 0.5h / 0.5km At the top of the ridge, follow the trail left to visit Stroms Lookout.
Follow Rock Point Trail right to the Daleys Point Trail carpark and reverse the instructions from there back to Woy Woy.
Plan your return trip from Woy Woy at transportnsw.info.

description: From Woy Woy's foreshore bike path, this walk traverses a surprisingly scenic ridgeline on the edge of Brisbane Water National Park overlooking the bay.
The final stretch to Gosford is along an excellent bike path around the wetlands.

markers.description: Get the train to Woy Woy using transportnsw.info.
From the station follow Brisbane Water Drive along along the railway.

markers.title: A Whale of a Time
explanation: One of the few remaining Krillz not pillz graffiti dotted around Central Coast.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Cross the bridge and go down the steps under the bridge immeately after.
- 1h / 2km Alternatively continue following the bike park along the bay to Point Claire.
Pass under the bridge and train line to Lare Street.
From the right side of Lara Street, follow the firetrail up the ridge.
After the steep climb follow the firetail along the ridge past several lookouts.

markers.title: Pretty but still Gosford
explanation: The prettiest side of Gosford, makes you suffer the climb to get here.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Cross Corrumbine Creek and continue the next ridge.
At the intersection follow the Milyerra Road Firetrail to the right.
Near the end of the firetrail, follow the bushtrail to the left.
Descend the steps down to Penang Street and follow Bribane Water Drive to the left.
Follow the path around the lake and head left down Yallambee Avenue. The alternative route continues from here.
Cross the highway and follow the footpath along the Pacific Highway left to Gosford Station.
Plan your return trip from Gosford at transportnsw.info.

description: This walk follows the waterfront foot and bike paths around Woy Woy to Umina Point.
From the spectacular Pearl Beach the walk leads inland
to the Crommelin Arboretum,
there the Patonga to Pearl Beach walking track leads up
to the Warrah Lookout.
After an optional side trip down to Patonga Beach,
the walk follows the Wondabyne to Patonga walking track to across Mount Wondabyne.
It then deviates from the Great North Walk to follow <a href="https://www.nationalparks.nsw.gov.au/things-to-do/cycling-trails/tommos-loop-and-rocky-ponds-cycling-loop">Tommos Loop<a/>
to Staples Lookout,
before continuing the fire trails up the ridge to the Bulgandry Art Site Aboriginal Place.
From there it crosses the road to continue to the legendary Gosford Glyphs,
before looping back to Woy Woy down the Koolewong firetrail.

markers.description: Get the train to Woy Woy using transportnsw.info.
From the station follow Railway Street to the ferry jetty.
From the jetty follow Brick Wharf Road along the shore.
Follow the footpath all the way around the waterfront.
At the end of the footpath, follow Blackwall Road to the bridge.
From the bridge follow Booker Bay Road to Ettalong Beach.
Follow the Esplanade to Umina Beach.
Follow Umina beach to the end past the holiday park.
+ 0.25h / 0.5km If the lagoon is flooded, walk around the holiday park instead.
From the lagoon follow Mount Ettalong Road to the left.
Follow the side trail to the left around Umina Point.
On the other side of Umina Point, follow Pearl Beach.
From the surf club, cross the bridge and follow Crystal Ave right.
At the Arboretum follow the Pearl Beach Patonga firetrail.
Warrah and several unfenced lookouts, can be found along the left side of the trail.

markers.title: I Can See My House from Here
explanation: Let the tourists enjoy the fenced lookout. Welcome to the club of locals who know better.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
+ 1.5h / 5km Optionally follow the steps down to Patonga Beach.
From the lookouts retrace your steps slightly back up the firetrail.
Near the first lookout across the firetrail, follow the steps up to the Warrah trig.
From the carpark at the trig, follow Warrah Trig Road.
Cross Patonga Drive and enter Waratah Patch Firetrail a short distance up the road.
This section is part of the Great North Walk. Follow the signs to Girakool.
Follow the Great North Walk markers left across the gully near the landfill.
Continue past the landfill up the ridge overlooking the park.

markers.title: The View is Garbage
explanation: With luck the wind is blowing away from it.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Follow the Great North Walk markers across the rocky plateaus.
At the intersection, follow Dillons Firetrail to the right.
Follow Dillons Firetrail to the landfill's gate.
Pass the gate and follow Nagari Road out of the landfill.
At the intersection, follow Railway Street to Woy Woy Station.
Plan your return trip from Woy Woy at transportnsw.info.

description: From Woy Woy's foreshore bike path, this walk traverses a surprisingly scenic ridgeline on the edge of Brisbane Water National Park overlooking the bay.
The final stretch to Gosford is along an excellent bike path around the wetlands.
From Rumbalara Reserve's visitor centre the walk ascends the prominent hill overlooking Gosford along a network of well maintained paths.
A lush trail follows the ridgeline connecting Rumbalara Reserve to Katandra Reserve at Mount Elliot.
From there quiet urban streets are followed down to Lisarow Station.

markers.description: Get the train to Woy Woy using transportnsw.info.
From the station follow Brisbane Water Drive along along the railway.

markers.title: A Whale of a Time
explanation: One of the few remaining Krillz not pillz graffiti dotted around Central Coast.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Cross the bridge and go down the steps under the bridge immeately after.
- 1h / 2km Alternatively continue following the bike park along the bay to Point Claire.
Pass under the bridge and train line to Lare Street.
From the right side of Lara Street, follow the firetrail up the ridge.
After th steep climb follow the firetail along the ridge past several lookouts.

markers.title: Pretty but still Gosford
explanation: The prettiest side of Gosford, makes you suffer the climb to get here.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Cross Corrumbine Creek and continue the next ridge.
At the intersection follow the Milyerra Road Firetrail to the right.
Near the end of the firetrail, follow the bushtrail to the left.
Descend the steps down to Penang Street and follow Bribane Water Drive to the left.
Follow the path around the lake and head left down Yallambee Avenue. The alternative route continues from here.
Cross the highway and follow the footpath to the right across the bridge and past a racing track.
Continue along the highway past the bridge over the railway tracks and continue along the lakefront.
From the reserve along the lake, follow Georgiana Terrace all the way uphill.
Turn left at the intersection with John Whiteway Dr to find the carpark of Rumbala Reserve on the right.
Ascend the steps from the carpark and follow the walking trail to the right and then up to the top of the hill.
+ 0.25h / 1km Optionally follow the Casuarina track around the picnic area.
Near the top of the hill, past the Rain Forest track, start following the Flannel Flower track.
The Flanel Flower track ends at a picnic area and lookout.
On the side of the road, past the lookout, the walking trail continues on the left.
One of the remaining statues of explorer is left along the trail.

markers.title: The Last Man Standing
explanation: There used to be 4 explorers dotted around this park. Only this one was hidden well enough from vandals.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
The trail ends at a picnic area and lookout of Katandra Reserve.
From the reserve follow Atkinson Road to the Taylor Road firetrail at the end.
Follow the Taylor Road firetrail across Mount Elliot.
From the intersection follow The Ridgeway left to Lisarow station.
Plan your return trip from Lisarow at transportnsw.info.

description: This walk follows the bike path along Woy Woy's waterfront, before ascending a very steep and challenging Koolewong firetrail.
It then loops around the legendary Gosford Glyphs hoax
to the Aboroginal rock engravings at the Bulgandry Art Site Aboriginal Place.
From there the firetrails follow along the ridgeline to Staples Lookout
before continuing as Tommos Loop to connect up with the Patonga walking track across Mount Wondabyne.
After completing the trek across Mount Wondabyne, this walk leaves the Patonga walking track at the intersection of firetrails and heads to the park exit at the Woy Woy landfill.

markers.description: Get the train to Woy Woy using transportnsw.info.
From the station follow Brisbane Water Drive along the railway line.

markers.title: A Whale of a Time
explanation: One of the few remaining Krillz not pillz graffiti dotted around Central Coast.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Cross the Spike Milligan bridge along the footpath.
Immediately after, take the steps down under the bridge.
walk under the bridge and the train line to Lara Street.
Immediately to the right a steep firetrail leads up the ridge.
Follow the firetrail along the ridgetop.
Several partially obscured lookouts can be found along the left of the trail.
At a sharp corner in the trail a ledge juts out providing a wide vista.

markers.title: Pretty but still Gosford
explanation: The prettiest side of Gosford, makes you suffer the climb to get here.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
- 0.5h / 1km Skip the Gosford Glyps by going left down Bambara Road.
Turn left down the Hieroglyphic Trail.
At the campground, follow the trail up the rocks.
Between two large boulders the Gosford Glyphs have been engraved in the walls.

markers.title: But Why Though?
explanation: Whomever made these ensured a lasting urban legend only the locals know.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Continue the scramble up the ridge and follow the beaten path to the firetrail a the top.
Follow the firetrail along the ridge.
Pass the gate and turn left down Woy Woy Road.
Follow Woy Woy Road past the carpark at Bambara Road
Watch for the gate on the right, a short distance along Woy Woy Road.
Pass the gate and follow the trail to the Bulgandry Aborigal Site.
Return to the carpark of the Bulgandry Aborigal Site along the paved footpath.
From the carpark follow the firetrail to the right along Woy Woy Road.
The firetrail soon veers away from Woy Woy road and follows the powerlines.
At the top of the quarie follow the trail back to Woy Woy Road.
From the trailhead cross Woy Woy Road into the Staples Lookout carpark.
Cross the carpark and picnic area to the lookout.
From Staples Lookout, continue left down Woy Woy Road.
Enter Tommos Loop Firetrail on the right a short distance down Woy Woy Road.
Continue down Tommos Loop Firetrail to the junction with the Great North Walk.
Follow the Great North Walk sign to the right down the Hawkesbury Track.
A narrow trail and boardwalks lead towards Mount Wondabyne.
At the junction with the Mullet Creek Firetrail follow the sign to the right.
On the left side of the Mullet Creek Firetrail a sign indicated the trail up Mount Wondabyne.
At the top of hill, a side trail to the left takes you to the summit of Mount Wondabyne.
+ 0.5h / 0.5km Optionally climb the summit of Mount Wondabyne.

markers.title: This is the End
explanation: The end is just the start of a new journey.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Follow the trail down the other side of Mount Wondabyne.
At the junction with the Tunnel Firetrail, follow the Great North Walks sign to the right.
Follow Dillons Firetrail where it intersects the Tunnel Firetrail.
Dillons Firetrail ends at the fence around the landfill. There a gap for pedestrians.
Follow the road out of the landfill past a second gate. A gap on the right allows pedestrians out.
Continue down Nagari Road past the self storage facility to the junction with Railway Street.
Follow Railway Street all the way back to Woy Woy Station.
Plan your return trip from Woy Woy at transportnsw.info.

description: This walk follows the coastal walk through part of Bouddi National Park.
It then follow the 5 Lands Walk to Terrigal, and continues along the coast through Wyrrabalong National Park.
From Bateau Bay the walk then cuts across to the Tuggerah Lake Cycle Way to Chittaway bay.

markers.description: Get the train to Woy Woy using transportnsw.info.
Exit the station across the pedestrian ramp.
Cross Brisbane Water drive and follow it left to the ferry dock.
From the ferry dock follow the bike path right along the shore front.
Cross Lions Park and continue along the waterfront.
At the end of the bike path, continue along the grass along the water.
Follow the road from boat ramp car park to Orange Grove Road.
Turn left onto Orange Grove Road and follow it along Blackwall Mountain.
Turn left to remain on Orange Grove Road before the underpass.
Take the rough path on the right up to Empire Bay Drive.
Cross Empire Bay Drive and follow it left to the bridge.
Cross the bridge across Brisbane Water.
On the other side of the bridge, take the ramp down to Daley Ave.
Follow Daley Ave past the house along the hillside.
Turn left onto Fisherman's Trail and follow it uphill.
At the junction, follow the trail left as it zigzags up the ridge.
At the intersection at the top of the ridge, follow the firetrail to the left.
At the next intersection, follow Daley's Point Trail to the right.
Exit the trail through the gate at the Wards Hill  carpark.
Cross Wards Hill Road and continue down Maitland Bay Drive.
Maitland Bay Drive ends at the Boudi National Park visitor centre.
From the car park follow the steps down to Maitland Bay.
Continue on past the intersection to the Bullimah Spur.
At the intersection with the coastal walk, continue left down to Maitland Bay.
At Maitland Bay, follow the beach to the other side.
Ascend the sandstone staircase up the headland.
At the intersection follow the coastal walk right to Little Beach.
At intersections with side trails, follow the signs to Little Beach.
At the last intersection continue left down the smaller Old Quarry bush trail.
From the end of the coastal walk folow the Bombi Moor Firetrail.
At the intersection follow Little Beach Trail to the right.
At the Little Beach campground, cross the stepstones across the creek.
Follow the coastal walk sign up the next headland.
Head left down the firetrail at the top of the headland.
Take the left track at the intersection with the 72 Trail.
Continue left past the second point trail.
Pass the gate at the end of the firetrail and continue along Beachview Esplanade.
At the intersection with Ocean Drive take the footpath between the houses on the right.
Continue down the bush trail behind the houses.
Pass the gate at the end of the trail and continue down Macmasters Parade.
At the corner take the steps down to Marine Parade on the right.
From Marine Parade use the beach access.

markers.title: Take Five: Macmaster
explanation: Secluded enough to wonder where everyone else is instead.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Follow the beach towards Copacabana on the other side.
After long periods of rain, the lagoon may be flooded and it'll be nessecary to wade across.
Leave the beach at the Copacabana Surf Club.

markers.title: Take Five: Copacabana
explanation: The climb up the headland will make you appreciate the shady beach below.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Continue right down Del Monte Place along the beach.
Continue straight past the two roundabouts and follow the road uphill.
+ 0.25h / 0km Turn right at the top to visit Captain Cook Lookout.
A bushtrail continues from the far end of the plaform between the fence and the warning sign in the photo.
The trail leads to a staircase down into Winnie Bay.
Follow the scaircase down and follow the path through the gully.
Continue down Del Monte Place and take the footpath into Captain Cook Park on the right.
Follow the steps down to Winnie Bay.
At the end of the steps cross Winnie Bay along the firetrail.
Past the waste water outlet, take the firetrail zigzag up the ridge.
Continue past the water tank at the top of the ridge.
Cross Endeavour Drive and find the steps down to Avoca between the houses.
Follow the steps all the way down, crossing the intersecting streets several times along the way.
At the bottom of the steps, entry the grassy reserve behind the surf club.
From the park, cross the surf club car park.

markers.title: Take Five: Avoca
explanation: Too tempting to hang around for a while.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Continue up Avoca beach from the surf club.
After wet weather Avoca lagoon may require wading as well.
Leave the beach at North Avoca's surf club.

markers.title: Take Five: North Avoca
explanation: On a hot day, the next climb might end it all.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Continue right up North Avoca Parade.
Turn right at The Arena and start the zigzag road up the ridge.
At the top cross the Scenic Highway and head down Kurawyba Ave.
At the end of Kurawyba Ave follow the narrow footpath down between the houses.
At the intersection follow Kurawyba Ave to the left.
Follow Kurawyba Ave all the way to Terrigal Beach.

markers.title: Take Five: Terrigal
explanation: A boulevard so full of icecream and treats, but the hilltop lookout on the horizon beckons.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Follow the esplanade left and continue along the beach towards Wamberal Lagoon.
After wet weather it may be nessecary to wade through Wamberal Lagoon.
Continue past Wamberal Lagoon to Forester Beach.
Find the steps up from the beach at the next headland.
From the beach access follow Spoon Bay Road.
Turn right up Kalakau Ave.
Follow Kalakau Road past Forester Beach.
After the bend turn right down North Scenic Road.
Pass the gate and continue past the radio tower into Wyrrabalong National Park.
Follow North Scenic Road towards the radio tower at the top. The last section is narrow and steep. Be mindful of descending cars.
Follow the coastal walk to Crackneck Lookout.

markers.title: Four Seasons in One Day: Coastal Heathland
explanation: The dense olive green heath opens up to the blues of open ocean and sky.
Once all of Central Coast was painted with the paints on this small pallete.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
At side trails, continue following the signs for the Coastal Walk.
Cross the car park at Crackneck Lookout.
Across the lookout carpark follow the steps down to Bateau Bay.
Follow the trail markers to Bateau Bay Beach.
Follow the footpath along Bateau Bay Beach and the picnic areas.
From the other side of the picnic areas, continue down the trail to the holiday park.
From the end of the trail, follow Bateau Bay Road past the holiday park.
At the intersection with Shelly Beach Road, follow Bateau Bay Road left past the caravans.
At the roundabout follow Yakalla Road Left.
Cross The Entrance Road at the traffic lights and follow it right along the footpath towards the Entrance.
At the next roundabout, follow Wyong Road to the left.
Cross Wyong Road at the traffic lights and turn right down McLean Street.
Turn left at the end of McLean Street and start following the bike path along the lake.
Follow the combined bike and footpath all the way  along lake Tuggerah

markers.title: All Jetty's Short and Long: Berkeley Vale
explanation: You might have to fight the pelicans for this one.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
The bike path leaves the lake at Chittaway Lions Park. Cross the road follow the footpath right for a short distance.
Turn left at the artificial wetlands and follow the footpath along the creek.
At the far end of the artificial wetlands turn right down James Watt Drive.
Turn left at the roundabout and follow Chittaway Road past the shopping centre.
Cross Wyong Road and follow it to the right in the direction of Tugerah.
Follow the footpath past the industrial estate.
At the roundabout near the Pacific Highway, cross Wyong Road and follow Bryant Drive to the right past the furniture stores.
Turn left after the furniture stores and continue across the carpark and bus stops to Tuggerah Station.
Plan your return trip from Tuggerah at transportnsw.info.

description: The start of the walk is mostly along suburban streets, but there's views across the Central Coast Wetlands and Tuggerah Lake.
The north end of the walk is along the cycleways around Lake Budgewoi and Lake Tuggerah.
On the far side of the loop around the lake, the walk passes through Wyrrabalong National Park.
The south part of the loop is along the Tuggerah Lake Cycleway.

markers.description: Get the train to Wyong at transportnsw.info.
Exit the station across the pedestrian bridge.
From the station carpark follow Warner Avenue.
Follow Boyce Road to the right.
Follow McDonagh Road to the left.
Follow the road along the river and turn left down Tuggerahwong Road at the carpark for the sports fields.

markers.title: All Jetty's Short and Long: Tacoma
explanation: It takes a day to walk around the lake to the side of the Wyong River across from here.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Follow Tuggerahwong road along the lake. There's a few places with lakeside access along the way.
Enter the carpark at Craigie Park on the right.
Follow the footpath through the park and out the other side.
At the far end of the park follow Mark's Road to the right.
Turn right into Lett Street and follow it to the boat ramp.
At the boat ramp, turn left and continue to the shops at Wallarah Road.
Follow the footpath along the shops and ceossbthe road into Wallarah Point Peace Park on the left.

markers.title: All Jetty's Short and Long: Gorokan
explanation: That bridge will cut 20 kilometres off your loop around the lake. Tempting?
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
From the park, follow the Corso to the right.
Turn left from the dog park at Orooaloo Point, then right to follow the Pacific Highway.
Cross the bridge over Wallarah Creek along the Pacific Highway.
Directly after the bridge turn right into the boat ramp carpark.

markers.title: All Jetty's Short and Long: San Remo
explanation: A vantage to enjoy the wetlands across Wallarah Creek.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
From the boat ramp follow the foot and bike path along the lake.
At the canal the path continues across the dam.

markers.title: All Jetty's Short and Long: Matumba
explanation: Halfway to Budgewoi where this unexpectedly nice shorefront bike path will come inevitably to an end.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
At Edgewater Park follow the path right to continue along the lake.
At the end of the bike path, follow the footpath up to the bridge.
Take the bridge across Budgewoi Creek.
Enter the reserve at the other side of the bridge.
The foot and bike path continues across the carpark.
Follow the bike path along the Central Coast Highway towards the Entrance.
Turn right down Oleander Street.
Follow Evans Road to the left.
At the end of Evans Road, pass the gate into Wyrrabalong National Park.
Follow the Wetlands trail and continue right down the Red Gum trail.

markers.title: Four Seasons in One Day: Wetlands
explanation: A short stretch of wetland makes a lush green welcome mat.
Once all of Central Coast was painted with the paints on this small pallete.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy

markers.title: Four Seasons in One Day: Red Gum Forest
explanation: A streak of vivid red and orange across the sandy ridge.
Once all of Central Coast was painted with the paints on this small pallete.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy

markers.title: Four Seasons in One Day: Rainforest
explanation: A green sky overhead as the rainforest covers the entire sky.
Once all of Central Coast was painted with the paints on this small pallete.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
From the intersection, continue ahead down the Lilly Pilly trail.
At the end of the trail, follow the Central Coast Highway to the right.
A short distance past the Magento Shores golf course turn right onto the bike path.
Follow the bike path through the bushland and past the holiday park.
Follow the bike path across the boat ramp's car park.

markers.title: All Jetty's Short and Long: The Entrance
explanation: A nice quiet waterway to prepare for the tourist bustle of the Entrance.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
Continue along the bike path to The Entrance bridge.
Cross the Entrance bridge along the footpath.
On Tue far side of the bridge take the ramp down to The Entrance foreshore.
From the bridge, follow the bike path through the the park around Picnic Point.
After the picnic area follow the bike path right around the lake.

markers.title: All Jetty's Short and Long: Long Jetty
explanation: Walking down this endless jetty feels like being wrapped in a blank sheet of paper.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy

markers.title: All Jetty's Short and Long: Watkin's Jetty
explanation: It's not as long, but also not as busy.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy

markers.title: All Jetty's Short and Long: Parry's Jetty
explanation: The third and last chance for a long jetty.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy

markers.title: All Jetty's Short and Long: Berkeley Vale
explanation: You might have to fight the pelicans for this one.
markers.description:
Visit this location to
earn the mystery trophy
The bike path finally leaves the lake at Chittaway Lions Park.
Cross the road and follow the bike path along the artificial wetlands.
Turn right down James Watt Drive.
Turn left at the roundabout and follow Chittaway Road.
Cross Wyong Road and follow it to the right along the bike path.
At the next roudabout, cross Wyong road and continue right past the carpark of the Furniture shops.
Follow Wyong Road to the left at the roundabout.
Turn left after the furniture stores to Tuggerah Station.
Plan your return trip from Tuggerah using transportnsw.info.

description: Just out of reach of public transport, Myall Lakes National Park is still close enough for a day trip.
This loop offers a nice variety of bush and beach trails, beachside picnic areas, and the Seal Rocks Lighthouse.

markers.description: There is space to park the car near the Hawks Nest Seal Rocks Road.
Follow the road past the gate and intersections with the Yagon Firetrail
Turn left at the intersection with the Middle Camp Trail and follow it towards the dunes.
At the intersection follow the disused road to the right to Middle Camp.
At the next intersection follow increasingly patchy trail through the dunes.
At the end of the trail, climb across the dune.
From the dunes at Middle Camp, follow the beach north towards the Yagon Headland.
At the headland follow the path from the beach to the Yagon Campground.
Follow the road across the campground.
From the entrance of the campground follow the road towards Seal Rocks.
Turn right and follow the Treachery Beach access to the dunes.
From the carpark follow the trail to the beach.
Follow the beach left towards Treachery Head.
At the headland ascend the stairs up the headland.
Follow the signs along the trail to the carpark.
From the carpark follow Thomas Road a short distance to the right to the next carpark.
Follow the sign to the Lighthouse Beach carpark.
From the carpark follow the path down to the beach.
Follow Lighthouse Beach to the left towards the lighthouse.
Mind that cars frequent this beach.
At the headland follow the stairs up to the lighthouse.
A short side trip to visit the lighthouse is on the right a the top of the beach access.
From the lighthouse follow Lighthouse Road to Seal Rocks.
Follow Kinka Road along Boat Beach.
At the end of Beach Beach there is a general store and cafe.
From the general store, follow the road or the short headland track to Number One Beach.
From the carpark across the holiday park follow Seal Rocks Road out of town.
To avoid the traffic use the sections of access trail along Seal Rocks Road.
The access trail will lead back to the intersection with Hawks Nest Seal Rocks Road.
